A gentleman says:

ice is made of water

Chapter Three: Not Seeking the Unnecessary
The gentleman does not value actions for their difficulty,
nor does he value speech for its cleverness,
nor does he value reputation for its widespread dissemination;
he values only what is appropriate.
Therefore, embracing a stone and plunging into the river
is a difficult thing to do,
and Shen Tu Di was able to do it;
however, the gentleman does not value it,
because it is not within the bounds of ritual and righteousness.
"Mountains and valleys are level,"

“When Qi and Qin attacked,

and exits the mouth,"
"A hook has a beard,"

However, the gentleman does not value them,
because they are not within the bounds of ritual and righteousness.
Robber Zhi's pronouncements
had a reputation like the sun and moon,
being transmitted alongside Yu and Shun without ceasing;
however, the gentleman does not value him,
because he is not within the bounds of ritual and righteousness.
Therefore, it is said:
In conduct, the gentleman does not value merely being difficult;
in speech, he does not value merely being discerning;
in reputation, he does not value merely obtaining it;
only valuing what is appropriate.

When a petty person is capable, he is arrogant, eccentric, and contrary, using this to haughtily overwhelm others;
when he is incapable, he is jealous, resentful, and slanderous, using this to subvert others.
Therefore, it is said:
When a gentleman is capable, people are honored and learn from him;
when he is incapable, people are happy to inform him.
When a petty person is capable, people despise learning from him;
when he is incapable, people are ashamed to inform him.
This is the distinction between a gentleman and a petty person.
A gentleman is generous without being lax,
honest without being cutting,
eloquent without being contentious,
observant without being harsh,
upright without being overbearing,
firm and strong without being violent,
yielding and compliant without being swept away,
To be respectful, cautious, and composed in demeanor,
that is what is called ultimate refinement.
The *Book of Poetry* says:
"Gentle and respectful is the accomplished person;
virtue is their foundation."
This is what that means.
When a gentleman esteems the virtue of others,
and praises their merits,
it is not flattery;
When one speaks with correct righteousness and directly points out,
and mentions the faults of others,
it is not destructive criticism;
When one speaks of one's own brilliance and beauty,
comparing oneself to Yu and Shun,
and aligning oneself with Heaven and Earth,
it is not exaggeration;
To yield and adapt with the times,
being as pliant and compliant as reeds,
is not timidity;
To be firm, strong, fierce, and resolute,
and to be trusted everywhere,
is not arrogance and tyranny.
It is to change and respond based on righteousness,
knowing when to bend and when to be straight.
The *Book of Poetry* says:
"If to the left, then to the left;
the gentleman finds it appropriate;
"When it is right, deem it right;
the superior man acts accordingly."
The superior man is the opposite of the petty man.
When his heart is cautious, he fears righteousness and practices moderation.
When wise, he is enlightened and understands categories.
When foolish, he is sincere and follows the law.
When he sees progress, he is respectful and stops at the right time.
When he sees obstruction, he is reverent and aligns himself.
When happy, he is harmonious and reasonable.
When successful, he is refined and clear.
When in difficulty, he is concise and detailed.
The petty man is not like this.
When his heart is expansive, he is arrogant and violent.
When his heart is cautious, he is dissolute and prone to excess.
When wise, he snatches and steals gradually.
When foolish, he is poisonous and destructive, causing chaos.
When he sees progress, he is flattering and haughty.
When he sees obstruction, he is resentful and treacherous.
When happy, he is frivolous and flighty.
When worried, he is defeated and fearful.
When successful, he is proud and biased.
When in difficulty, he gives up and is cowardly.
The *Commentary* says:
"The superior man progresses in two ways;
the petty man fails in two ways."
This is what it means.
The superior man governs when there is order;
he does not govern when there is chaos.
What does this mean?
To necessarily wait for an event before acting in a certain way
is called artificiality (偽).
This is where human nature (性) and artificiality originate,
and this is the distinguishing characteristic that sets them apart.
Therefore, the sage transforms human nature and gives rise to artificiality;
artificiality arises (from trustworthiness 信) and gives rise to ritual and righteousness;
ritual and righteousness give rise to the establishment of laws and standards.
Therefore, ritual, righteousness, laws, and standards
are what the sage brings into being.
Therefore, the reason the sage is the same as the multitude,
the way in which he is no different from the multitude,
is in his human nature.
